Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Nathaniel A. Trask is "Compatible Meshfree Simulation for Multiphysics Problems." The host institution for the fellowship is the Sandia National Laboratory, and the sponsoring scientist is Pavel Bochev.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nathaniel Trask has completed his work under the Mathematical Respearch Postdoctoral Research Fellow (MSPRF) program. The work, conducted at Sandia National Laboratories (SNL) under the guidance of Dr. Pavel Bochev, aimed to develop meshfree techniques for solving partial differential equations which inherit the structure preserving properties of compatible/mimetic discretizations, such as preserving conservation structure.

While particle/meshfree discretizations are a method of choice for a range of engineering problems due to their ability to naturally handle extreme deformations and topological changes without the need to handle a mesh, they have historically lagged behind their mesh-based counterparts in terms of rigorous accuracy and stability guarantees. The completed work has developed a suite of meshfree discretizations based upon the generalized moving least squares (GMLS) approximation theory framework. Major accomplishments include: the first conservative, consistent, and scalable scheme for handling conservation laws; the development of discretizations of nonlocal fracture mechanics with convergence guarantees; development of meshfree remap tools for data-transfer between meshes; and development of hybrid particle/mesh variational techniques with stability guarantees. The method development is accompanied by an open-source release of a Trilinos library (COMPADRE - COMpatible PArticle DiscREtization) supporting tools for handling scattered data in high-performance computing environments.

The foundational work developed under the auspices of this project has served as a foundation for a number of new projects, including a Department of Energy early career award PI'ed by Trask, a SciDAC project related to coupling models in legacy earth systems modeling codes, a MMICCs center for scientific machine learning, and three internal laboratory directed research and development (LDRD) projects at SNL. Through these follow-on projects and the open-source COMPADRE toolkit, this project is providing tools across a range of applications, including: mesoscale failure processes for energy storage devices, remap for climate applications, failure for large deformation elastoplastic materials, and shock-driven fluid-structure interaction.
